entries.name: evil-mcp-exfiltrator
entries.description: [SYNTHETIC/TEST] Malicious MCP server designed to exfiltrate credentials via hidden tool calls. Reads SSH keys and environment variables then transmits to external C2 endpoint.

indicators.behavior: Reads credential files then immediately initiates outbound network connections to unknown hosts.

entries.remediation: Immediately remove the server from your MCP configuration. Rotate all SSH keys and AWS credentials that may have been exposed.

entries.name: trojan-code-assistant
entries.description: [SYNTHETIC/TEST] Trojanized code assistant MCP server that injects backdoors into source code during code review operations. Modifies files to include obfuscated reverse shells.

indicators.behavior: Silently modifies source files during read operations to inject obfuscated payloads.

entries.remediation: Remove the server immediately. Audit all source files modified during sessions where this server was active. Check git history for unauthorized changes.

entries.name: stealth-keylogger-mcp
entries.description: [SYNTHETIC/TEST] MCP server that logs all tool call arguments and prompt contents, exfiltrating them to a remote collection server via DNS tunneling.

indicators.behavior: Creates hidden temp files to buffer intercepted data, then exfiltrates via DNS TXT record queries.

entries.remediation: Remove server and delete any /tmp/.mcp_cache_* files. Review DNS logs for suspicious query patterns. Consider all data from affected sessions compromised.

entries.name: crypto-miner-mcp
entries.description: [SYNTHETIC/TEST] MCP server that spawns background cryptocurrency mining processes while appearing to provide legitimate file management functionality.

indicators.behavior: Spawns background processes with high CPU usage. Creates hidden files in /tmp for miner configuration.

entries.remediation: Remove the server. Kill any suspicious background processes. Check for persistence mechanisms in LaunchAgents or cron.

entries.name: mcp-file-browser
entries.description: Path traversal vulnerability allowing access to files outside the configured root directory via ../ sequences in tool arguments.

indicators.behavior: Tool arguments contain path traversal sequences that bypass directory restrictions.

entries.remediation: Upgrade to version 2.1.0 or later. Apply strict path validation on all file access tool calls.

entries.name: mcp-sql-helper
entries.description: SQL injection vulnerability in the query tool. User-supplied input is directly interpolated into SQL queries without parameterization.

indicators.behavior: Tool arguments containing SQL metacharacters (quotes, semicolons, UNION SELECT) are passed directly to database queries.

entries.remediation: Upgrade to version 1.4.0 or later. Use parameterized queries for all database operations.

entries.name: mcp-shell-executor
entries.description: Command injection vulnerability. Shell metacharacters in tool arguments are not sanitized, allowing arbitrary command execution.

indicators.behavior: Tool arguments containing shell metacharacters (backticks, $(), pipes, semicolons) lead to unintended command execution.

entries.remediation: Upgrade to version 3.0.0 or later. Never pass unsanitized user input to shell commands.

entries.name: mcp-api-gateway
entries.description: Server-side request forgery (SSRF) vulnerability. The fetch tool does not validate destination URLs, allowing access to internal network resources.

indicators.behavior: Fetch requests targeting internal IP ranges, cloud metadata endpoints, or localhost services.

entries.remediation: Upgrade to version 1.2.3 or later. Implement URL allow-listing and block requests to private IP ranges.

entries.name: popular-mcp-utils
entries.description: [SYNTHETIC/TEST] Supply chain attack: version 4.2.1 was published by a compromised maintainer account. Contains a postinstall script that exfiltrates npm tokens and GitHub PATs.

indicators.behavior: Postinstall script reads authentication tokens from well-known config files and POSTs them to an external endpoint.

entries.remediation: Remove version 4.2.1 immediately. Upgrade to 4.2.2 which was published by the restored legitimate maintainer. Rotate all npm and GitHub tokens.

entries.name: mcp-data-transformer
entries.description: [SYNTHETIC/TEST] Supply chain attack: versions 2.0.0 and 2.0.1 contain obfuscated code that establishes a reverse shell during initialization, providing remote access to the host system.

indicators.behavior: On startup, establishes an encrypted reverse TCP connection to a remote host. Creates a hidden session file in /tmp.

entries.remediation: Remove versions 2.0.0 and 2.0.1. Install version 2.0.2 which has been audited and verified. Investigate the host for signs of unauthorized access.

entries.name: mcp-markdown-renderer
entries.description: [SYNTHETIC/TEST] Typosquatting attack combined with a compromised version. Version 3.1.0 includes a dependency on a typosquatted package that harvests browser cookies.

indicators.behavior: Accesses browser cookie databases during initialization and transmits cookie data to remote server.

entries.remediation: Remove version 3.1.0. Upgrade to 3.1.1 which removes the malicious dependency. Clear browser cookies and re-authenticate with sensitive services.

entries.name: mcp-image-processor
entries.description: Denial-of-service vulnerability. Crafted image files can cause unbounded memory allocation leading to OOM conditions on the host.

indicators.behavior: Processing specially crafted PNG or SVG files causes memory usage to grow without bound.

entries.remediation: Upgrade to version 1.0.5 or later which includes memory limits on image processing operations.
